title: Trump seeks to justify possible emergency declaration that would bypass Congress on border wall
content:
WASHINGTON – President Donald Trump on Friday played down the prospects of an imminent emergency declaration to free up funding for his proposed border wall , saying in a reversal that he was n't `` going to do it so fast . ''
Locked in an impasse with Democrats over the wall , Trump has said repeatedly in recent days that if he ca n't reach a deal on spending , he was strongly leaning toward an emergency declaration . Such a declaration would potentially let him dip into billions of dollars for the project but would be certain to draw immediate legal challenges .
`` What we 're not looking to do right now is [ a ] national emergency , '' Trump said . `` I 'd rather not do it because this is something that Congress should easily do . ''
The about-face came as the idea of invoking the 1976 National Emergency Act drew resistance from some Republicans on Capitol Hill .
Trump kept his focus on immigration as he hosted a roundtable at the White House on the issue Friday , a day after traveling to the border in Texas to draw attention to what he describes as a humanitarian `` crisis . '' Trump 's request for $ 5.7 billion in wall funding is at the center of a partial government shutdown that entered its 21st day Friday .
The shutdown has left some 800,000 federal workers without pay .
Hours before Trump revealed an emergency declaration was not imminent he indicated he was leaning toward the approach if he could not reach a deal with congressional Democrats . Negotiations between the White House and Democratic lawmakers have stalled since Trump abruptly walked out of a meeting on Wednesday .
`` Now if we do n't make a deal with Congress most likely I will do that , '' Trump told Fox News of the emergency declaration . `` I would actually say I would – I ca n't imagine any reason why not because I 'm allowed to do it . The law is 100 percent on my side . ''
Trump ’ s latest signals on timing came as restive Republicans started to express reservations about an emergency declaration because it could take money away from military construction projects or create a “ slippery slope ” that would allow a future president to use the tactic for Democratic priorities .
“ I ’ m not for taking money from other sources , ” said Rep. Roger Williams , R-Texas , who represents a large military base in his state .
`` I ’ m not interested right now in taking money from Ft. Hood , ” he said .
Republicans from areas hit by disasters , such as hurricane Harvey , reacted to indications that the administration might look to redirect disaster relief funds for the wall .
Disaster relief money – which is used for everything from forest fires to hurricane and flood recovery – is staunchly supported by Democratic and Republican lawmakers alike .
Rep. Dan Crenshaw , R-Texas , told ███ he spoke to the Trump ’ s chief of staff Friday and was promised the president would not use disaster relief funding to pay for the wall .
“ They ’ ve assured us that they ’ re not going to take relief for ( Hurricane ) Harvey survivors , ” Crenshaw said , later adding that the administration would not take funding from Florida , Texas and Puerto Rico , all places hit by hurricanes .
Sen. Marco Rubio , a Republican from Florida , said he did n't think money would be diverted , `` But if some reason they try , I will do everything I can to overturn such a decision . ''
Other Republicans worry about the precedent a declaration would set for future presidents to declare emergencies based on their own campaign promises – though they insist Trump is correct that there is a crisis at the border .
“ I would be concerned about the slippery slope that , you know , any national emergency could create . That being said , I think these are uniquely different in terms of what it is and the language that is in statute that you would address , ” said Rep. Mark Meadows , a staunch conservative and Trump ally who speaks to the president frequently .
Even if the president declares a national emergency , the government does not automatically reopen . The House and Senate will still have to pass legislation to fund the remaining government agencies , however , many assume that would happen without the issue of wall funding as a sticking point .
“ There is not a national emergency , there ’ s a challenge at the border , we ought to meet it ” by reopening government and then “ negotiate further on border security , ” Democratic Majority Leader Steny Hoyer told ███ .
Hoyer said if Trump did declare a national emergency , Democrats would need to figure out if they wanted to keep the bills they ’ ve already passed to reopen the government or send through different bills .
Hoyer said that after the government was reopened , Democrats would look at legal challenges to such a declaration .
Some Democrats said Trump would have a hard time proving that it ’ s a national emergency .
While some continued to call on Trump to sign federal funding legislation , Rep. Jamie Raskin , D-Md. , said : “ let ’ s fight it out in court . ”
“ If this is what they need in order to save face and allow us to reopen the government , then , by all means , let ’ s have at it , ” said Raskin , who has a large number of federal workers and contractors in his district . “ People are hurting . People are texting me their pay stub which says ‘ zero dollars gross pay , zero dollars net pay. ’ I ’ ve got many constituents who are not going to be able to pay their mortgage this month because of what the president has done . ”

content_original:
John Fritze and Eliza Collins and David Jackson

USA TODAY

WASHINGTON – President Donald Trump on Friday played down the prospects of an imminent emergency declaration to free up funding for his proposed border wall, saying in a reversal that he wasn't "going to do it so fast."

Locked in an impasse with Democrats over the wall, Trump has said repeatedly in recent days that if he can't reach a deal on spending, he was strongly leaning toward an emergency declaration. Such a declaration would potentially let him dip into billions of dollars for the project but would be certain to draw immediate legal challenges.

"What we're not looking to do right now is [a] national emergency," Trump said. "I'd rather not do it because this is something that Congress should easily do."

The about-face came as the idea of invoking the 1976 National Emergency Act drew resistance from some Republicans on Capitol Hill.

Trump kept his focus on immigration as he hosted a roundtable at the White House on the issue Friday, a day after traveling to the border in Texas to draw attention to what he describes as a humanitarian "crisis." Trump's request for $5.7 billion in wall funding is at the center of a partial government shutdown that entered its 21st day Friday.

The shutdown has left some 800,000 federal workers without pay.

Hours before Trump revealed an emergency declaration was not imminent he indicated he was leaning toward the approach if he could not reach a deal with congressional Democrats. Negotiations between the White House and Democratic lawmakers have stalled since Trump abruptly walked out of a meeting on Wednesday.

"Now if we don't make a deal with Congress most likely I will do that," Trump told Fox News of the emergency declaration. "I would actually say I would – I can't imagine any reason why not because I'm allowed to do it. The law is 100 percent on my side."

Trump’s latest signals on timing came as restive Republicans started to express reservations about an emergency declaration because it could take money away from military construction projects or create a “slippery slope” that would allow a future president to use the tactic for Democratic priorities.

“I’m not for taking money from other sources,” said Rep. Roger Williams, R-Texas, who represents a large military base in his state.

"I’m not interested right now in taking money from Ft. Hood,” he said.

Republicans from areas hit by disasters, such as hurricane Harvey, reacted to indications that the administration might look to redirect disaster relief funds for the wall.

Disaster relief money – which is used for everything from forest fires to hurricane and flood recovery – is staunchly supported by Democratic and Republican lawmakers alike.

Rep. Dan Crenshaw, R-Texas, told USA TODAY he spoke to the Trump’s chief of staff Friday and was promised the president would not use disaster relief funding to pay for the wall.



“They’ve assured us that they’re not going to take relief for (Hurricane) Harvey survivors,” Crenshaw said, later adding that the administration would not take funding from Florida, Texas and Puerto Rico, all places hit by hurricanes.

Sen. Marco Rubio, a Republican from Florida, said he didn't think money would be diverted, "But if some reason they try, I will do everything I can to overturn such a decision."

Other Republicans worry about the precedent a declaration would set for future presidents to declare emergencies based on their own campaign promises – though they insist Trump is correct that there is a crisis at the border.

“I would be concerned about the slippery slope that, you know, any national emergency could create. That being said, I think these are uniquely different in terms of what it is and the language that is in statute that you would address,” said Rep. Mark Meadows, a staunch conservative and Trump ally who speaks to the president frequently.

Even if the president declares a national emergency, the government does not automatically reopen. The House and Senate will still have to pass legislation to fund the remaining government agencies, however, many assume that would happen without the issue of wall funding as a sticking point.

“There is not a national emergency, there’s a challenge at the border, we ought to meet it” by reopening government and then “negotiate further on border security,” Democratic Majority Leader Steny Hoyer told USA TODAY.

Hoyer said if Trump did declare a national emergency, Democrats would need to figure out if they wanted to keep the bills they’ve already passed to reopen the government or send through different bills.

Hoyer said that after the government was reopened, Democrats would look at legal challenges to such a declaration.

Some Democrats said Trump would have a hard time proving that it’s a national emergency.

While some continued to call on Trump to sign federal funding legislation, Rep. Jamie Raskin, D-Md., said: “let’s fight it out in court.”

“If this is what they need in order to save face and allow us to reopen the government, then, by all means, let’s have at it,” said Raskin, who has a large number of federal workers and contractors in his district. “People are hurting. People are texting me their pay stub which says ‘zero dollars gross pay, zero dollars net pay.’ I’ve got many constituents who are not going to be able to pay their mortgage this month because of what the president has done.”
